conclusion: An electron is moving through a uniform electric field between two parallel metal plates.
The electron is injected with an initial velocity v0 = 4 x 10^6 m/s perpendicular to the electric field.
When the electron exits the field at point C, its velocity makes a 30° angle with the initial velocity direction.
The task is to find the kinetic energy of the electron at point C in joules.
There are two parallel plates, A and B, with opposite charges, creating a uniform electric field.
The electron is injected along the central line perpendicular to the electric field direction.

premise: The electric field is uniform and perpendicular to the initial velocity.
conclusion: The electron will experience a constant force perpendicular to its initial motion.

premise: The electron experiences a constant force perpendicular to its initial motion.
conclusion: The electron will have a constant acceleration perpendicular to its initial velocity.

premise: The electron's motion can be broken down into two components: horizontal motion with constant velocity v0, and vertical motion with constant acceleration.
conclusion: At point C, the electron's velocity will have both horizontal and vertical components.
The kinetic energy at point C is given by KE = 1/2 m v^2, where m is the mass of the electron and v is its speed at point C.

premise: The angle θ = 30° is the angle between the initial velocity direction and the velocity at point C.
conclusion: The components of the velocity vector at point C can be related by tan(θ) = vy/vx = vy/v0.

premise: Given θ = 30° and vx = v0 = 4 x 10^6 m/s, tan(30°) = vy/v0.
vx = 4 x 10^6 m/s and vy ≈ 2.308 x 10^6 m/s.
conclusion: The speed v at point C is v = √(vx^2 + vy^2).
